text: Informational Writing: Reports, Procedures, or Persuasive Writing- Using Elaboration Strategies

children.text: In informational writing (reports or procedures only), students demonstrate use of a range of elaboration strategies by …
Using pictures to illustrate details/information related to topic (pictures may include labels) (Local)
In informational writing (reports or procedures only), students demonstrate use of a range of elaboration strategies by …
Including details/information relevant to topic (details/information may take the form of pictures with captions, "words," "sentences," or some combination) (Local)
In informational writing (reports or procedures only), students demonstrate use of a range of elaboration strategies by …
Including details/information relevant to topic and/or focus (Local)
Using sufficient details/pictures to illustrate facts (Local)
In informational writing (reports and procedures only), students demonstrate use of a range of elaboration strategies by…
Including details/information relevant to topic and/or focus (Local)
Including sufficient details for appropriate depth of information: naming, describing, explaining, comparing, use of visual images (Local)

text: Writing Conventions: Applying Rules of Grammar, Usage, and Mechanics

children.text: In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions by…
Using phonemic awareness and letter knowledge to spell independently (using phonetic or temporary spelling) and logically representing consonant sounds (e.g., initial or final sounds) (Local)
In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions by…
Using phonemic awareness and letter knowledge to spell independently (using phonetic or temporary spelling when needed) (Local)
Correctly spelling many common words (e.g., had, can, including own first name) (Local)
In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions by…
Using capital letters for the beginning of sentences and names (Local)
Using correct end punctuation in simple sentences (e.g., period) (Local)
Correctly spelling grade-appropriate, high-frequency words (Local)
Correctly spelling most words with regularly spelled patterns (e.g., consonant-vowel-consonant, CVC with silent e, one syllable words with blends) (Local)
Giving a readable and accurate phonetic spelling for words that have not been taught (Local)
In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions by…
Using capital letters for the beginning of sentences and names (Local)
Using end punctuation correctly in simple sentences (i.e., period, question mark, exclamation point) (Local)
Correctly spelling grade-appropriate, highfrequency words and using within-word patterns to correct spelling (Local)
In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions by…
Identifying grammatical errors, when given examples (State)
Applying basic capitalization rules (State)
Using commas correctly in dates and in a series (Note: either form is correct – x, y, and z or x, y and z) (State)
Using end punctuation correctly in a variety of sentence structures (State)
Correctly spelling grade-appropriate, high-frequency words and recognizing syllables and affix patterns/rules that are characteristic of the English spelling system (State)

text: Oral Communication Strategies: Make Oral Presentations

children.text: In oral communication, students make oral presentations by…
Speaking clearly and distinctly, orally sharing information and experiences (Local)
Demonstrating an awareness of options of language (e.g., imitating speech patterns and identifying source of sounds, interpreting nonverbal messages through pictures) (Local)
Telling stories about pictures, books or experiences (Local)
Providing feedback to audience (Local)
Recognizing role of audience (Local)
In oral communication, students make oral presentations by…
Orally ordering ideas in a sequence or telling a familiar story (Local)
Using various forms of linguistic elements and structures (e.g., saying "Please" in a command, asking about the weather as a form of polite address, stating a question in affirmative form) (Local)
Telling/retelling stories using details (Local)
Providing appropriate feedback to audience (Local)
Recognizing role of audience (Local)

Orally ordering ideas in a sequence, carrying on a conversation, asking and answering questions (Local)

Providing appropriate feedback to audience (Local)
Using strategies to engage audience (e.g., using eye-contact and adjustment of rate and volume) (Local)
